Tools.essentialTools: Essential tools for living in Korea.
Tools.calcBasis: The calculation is based on the 2025 tax rates and 4 major insurance policies in South Korea.
Tools.nationalPension: National Pension (4.5%): Capped at a monthly income of 5.9 million KRW.
Tools.healthInsurance: Health Insurance (3.545%): Mandatory for all employees.
Tools.longTermCare: Long-term Care Insurance (12.95% of Health Ins.): Additional charge on top of health insurance.
Tools.incomeTax: Income Tax: Calculated based on the simplified tax table provided by the National Tax Service.
Tools.estimationDisclaimer: * This is an estimation. Actual amount may vary depending on company policies and year-end tax settlement.
Tools.renewReminder: Make sure to renew or leave before this date.
Tools.visaExpiryImportance: Calculating your visa expiry date correctly is crucial to avoid overstaying fines or entry bans.
Tools.entryDateDesc: The day you arrived in Korea (Day 1).
Tools.durationDesc: The number of days you are allowed to stay.
Tools.expiryDateDesc: The last day you can legally be in Korea. You must leave ON or BEFORE this date.
Tools.visaNote: * Note: This calculator assumes the entry date is counted as Day 1 or Day 0 depending on specific visa types. Generally, for short-term visitors (B-1, B-2), the count starts the day after entry. Please verify with the immigration office (1345) for your specific case. This tool uses a simple date addition logic.
Tools.unitExplanation: In Korea, the traditional unit "Pyeong" (평) is still widely used in real estate, despite the official use of square meters.
Tools.unitNote: When looking for apartments, you will often see sizes like "24 Pyeong" or "33 Pyeong". These usually refer to the "Supply Area" (공급면적), which includes shared spaces like hallways and elevators, not just the "Exclusive Area" (전용면적) inside the apartment.
Tools.exchangeRateNote: Exchange rates are updated daily. The rates shown here are mid-market rates and may differ from the rates offered by your bank or money transfer service.
Tools.exchangeTip: Tip: When transferring money internationally, services like Wise or Remitly often offer better rates than traditional banks.
